title: Advanced Type Aliases
snippet: Create flexible type aliases including generics
description: Advanced type alias patterns include aliasing function pointer types, complex pointer types, and generic instantiations. Aliases can dramatically improve readability of complex type signatures. For example, 'type Handler = void (*)(int, string)' is clearer than repeating the full signature everywhere. Aliases are especially valuable when refactoring - change the alias definition instead of updating every usage. They enable progressive type refinement: start with 'type ID = int', later change to 'type ID = i64' without touching consuming code. Combine with generics for powerful abstractions. This example shows advanced aliasing techniques for complex scenarios.
code: printf("Name: %s, Age: %d, Score: %.1f\n", myName, myAge, myScore);
